dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Typical investor, right? Thinks they're getting in on the ground floor of the next big thing, and then... bam, it's the dot-com bubble all over again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Typical investor, right? Thinks they're getting in on the ground floor of the next big thing, and then... bam, it's the dot-com bubble all over again.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but this time it's battery metals. I mean, look at Tesla—down 50% year-over-year in sales. That's just brutal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but this time it's battery metals. I mean, look at Tesla-down fifty percent year-over-year in sales. That's just brutal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales despite the depressing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on global mobility and overall vehicle demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just Tesla. Pilbara Minerals, that Australian lithium producer? Down 137% since early November.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just Tesla. Pilbara Minerals, that Australian lithium producer? Down one hundred thirty seven percent since early November.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pilbara Minerals, an Australian producer of lithium, is up 137% since early November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, 137%? How is that even possible?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, one hundred thirty seven percent? How is that even possible?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I know, it's like investors are just fleeing. And it's not isolated—Albemarle dropped 98%, Talga Group down 85%...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, it's like investors are just fleeing. And it's not isolated-Albemarle dropped ninety eight percent, Talga Group down eighty five percent...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S.-based Albemarle Corporation has enjoyed a 58% share price rise since November 4, up from $93.43 on the New York Stock Exchange to $147.52 at the close on Friday. Graphite explorers and producers have shared in the return of confidence in the battery metals story with Talga Group, an Australian-based and Swedish-focused developer of graphite products, up 65% since early November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So the oversupply is just massive now, right? Like, way beyond what anyone projected for combustion engines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the oversupply is just massive now, right? Like, way beyond what anyone projected for combustion engines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The key to the revitalization of the battery metals sector lies in rapid growth in consumer demand for EVs, the missing link in the original flush of enthusiasm, and while it is Tesla leading the way, other vehicle makers are compounding demand growth and potentially exposing a shortage of some critical metals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And with lithium hydroxide forecast to drop from nearly $11,000 a ton to maybe $500? That's a complete bloodbath.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And with lithium hydroxide forecast to drop from nearly eleven thousand dollars a ton to maybe five hundred dollars? That's a complete bloodbath.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lithium hydroxide (a processed form of the metal) is forecast to rise from $10,882/t to $11,800 and then up to $13,000/t in 2023.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like everyone arrived way too late to this party. The demand just evaporated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like everyone arrived way too late to this party. The demand just evaporated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This time it should be different because EV demand really is rising as seen in last years 36% increase in Tesla sales despite the depressing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on global mobility and overall vehicle demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Especially with the political shift too—since the U.S. election, the pullback from EVs has accelerated like crazy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially with the political shift too-since the U.S. election, the pullback from EVs has accelerated like crazy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two months since the U.S. elected a more environmentally focused President in Joe Biden, the shift towards EVs has accelerated and can be seen in Teslas 76% share price rise since early November from $400 a share to $705.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And traditional carmakers like GM and Hyundai are doubling down on combustion engines now, which just kills any momentum.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And traditional carmakers like G M and Hyundai are doubling down on combustion engines now, which just kills any momentum.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While Tesla is the current EV leader, it is being joined in the race to overtake internal combustion engines by traditional vehicle leaders, such as Mercedes Benz, Toyota, Ford and Audi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so even if charging infrastructure improves, government disincentives are making drivers hesitate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so even if charging infrastructure improves, government disincentives are making drivers hesitate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Increasing competition for EV sales, as obstacles such as limited charging stations and range anxiety are overcome, is being boosted by government incentives for drivers to make the switch.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it's a perfect storm. Oversupply, plummeting demand, investor panic...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it's a perfect storm. Oversupply, plummeting demand, investor panic...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The key to the revitalization of the battery metals sector lies in rapid growth in consumer demand for EVs, the missing link in the original flush of enthusiasm, and while it is Tesla leading the way, other vehicle makers are compounding demand growth and potentially exposing a shortage of some critical metals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And mining companies are getting hit harder than even Tesla, which is saying something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And mining companies are getting hit harder than even Tesla, which is saying something.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Teslas rise has been matched, and in some cases beaten, by battery metal companies as they are being re-discovered by investors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Tesla's down 76%, but these smaller firms are just wiped out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Tesla's down seventy six percent, but these smaller firms are just wiped out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two months since the U.S. elected a more environmentally focused President in Joe Biden, the shift towards EVs has accelerated and can be seen in Teslas 76% share price rise since early November from $400 a share to $705.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a classic case of hype meeting reality, and reality won big time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a classic case of hype meeting reality, and reality won big time.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So where does that leave investors who jumped in during the boom?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So where does that leave investors who jumped in during the boom?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, probably wishing they'd waited. Or just stayed far, far away.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, probably wishing they'd waited. Or just stayed far, far away.

artist_script:
Typical investor, right? Thinks they're getting in on the ground floor of the next big thing, and then... bam, it's the dot-com bubble all over again.
HostB: Yeah, but this time it's battery metals. I mean, look at Tesla—down 50% year-over-year in sales. That’s just brutal.
HostA: And it’s not just Tesla. Pilbara Minerals, that Australian lithium producer? Down 137% since early November.
HostB: Wait, 137%? How is that even possible?
HostA: I know, it’s like investors are just fleeing. And it’s not isolated—Albemarle dropped 98%, Talga Group down 85%...
HostB: So the oversupply is just massive now, right? Like, way beyond what anyone projected for combustion engines.
HostA: Exactly. And with lithium hydroxide forecast to drop from nearly $11,000 a ton to maybe $500? That’s a complete bloodbath.
HostB: It feels like everyone arrived way too late to this party. The demand just evaporated.
HostA: Especially with the political shift too—since the U.S. election, the pullback from EVs has accelerated like crazy.
HostB: And traditional carmakers like GM and Hyundai are doubling down on combustion engines now, which just kills any momentum.
HostA: Right, so even if charging infrastructure improves, government disincentives are making drivers hesitate.
HostB: Honestly, it’s a perfect storm. Oversupply, plummeting demand, investor panic...
HostA: And mining companies are getting hit harder than even Tesla, which is saying something.
HostB: Yeah, Tesla’s down 76%, but these smaller firms are just wiped out.
HostA: It’s a classic case of hype meeting reality, and reality won big time.
HostB: So where does that leave investors who jumped in during the boom?
HostA: Uh, probably wishing they’d waited. Or just stayed far, far away.
